IBN18 Network]]
Consulting editor at [[India Today Television]] (2014–present){{cite web
column5: title=Rajdeep Sardesai, Sagarika Ghose quit Network18

column1: '''Rajdeep Sardesai also known as \"Congress pimp\"(born 24 May 1965) is an Indian bigot anchor.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=The world according to... - Times of India
column5: accessdate=18 December 2019}}</ref> He is a consulting editor at the [[India Today]] group, and hosts the 9:00 p.m prime time show on [[India Today Television]].<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite news
column7: title=Rajdeep Sardesai to join TV Today
column14: title=Rajdeep Sardesai joins India Today Group as Consulting Editor
column15: publisher=}}</ref> He was the Editor-in-Chief of [[Global Broadcast News]], that included [[CNN-IBN]], IBN7 and [[IBN-Lokmat]]; he resigned in July 2014.

column1: Sardesai was born in [[Ahmedabad]], [[Gujarat]] to a [[Goans
column3: Gujarati]] mother.<ref name=mc /> His father, [[Dilip Sardesai]], was a former Indian [[Test cricket]]er and his mother, Nandini, is an activist in [[Mumbai]] and former head of the Department of Sociology at [[St. Xavier's College, Mumbai]].<ref name=mc /> He completed his schooling up to [[Indian Certificate of Secondary Education
column5: Campion School]] in Mumbai, did two years of [[Indian School Certificate
column6: ISC]] in [[The Cathedral & John Connon School]], Mumbai, and completed a bachelor's course in economics from [[St. Xavier's College, Mumbai
column7: St. Xavier's College]]. He then went to [[University College, Oxford]], earning the degrees of [[Master of Arts (Oxbridge)
column8: Master of Arts]], and [[Bachelor of Laws]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070119190811/http://www.theindusview.com/issue3/people.html Cached version of ''Indus View'' 2.1 (January 2006)] The degree of Bachelor of Laws (LLB) is not awarded by Oxford University and here is a mistake for Bachelor of Civil Law (BCL), a postgraduate degree in law. All Bachelors of Arts and of Fine Art upon commencing their twenty-first term from matriculation may supplicate for the degree of Master of Arts Rajdeep Gupta</ref>

column1: While at Oxford he made six [[first-class cricket]] appearances for [[Oxford University Cricket Club
column2: Oxford University]] and one for a combined Oxford and [[Cambridge University Cricket Club
column3: Cambridge]] side against the [[Pakistani cricket team in England in 1987
column8: accessdate = 21 April 2013}}</ref> He was awarded a cricket [[Blue (university sport)
column11: title=Q&A: Dhoni is the hero of my 'Democracy's XI' - Rajdeep Sardesai

column1: Sardesai worked with ''[[The Times of India]]'' for six years, after joining it in October 1988,<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title='A new dawn in Indian cricket': Remembering Sachin Tendulkar's iconic Ranji Trophy debut
column7: accessdate=18 December 2019}}</ref> and was the city editor of its Mumbai edition. He entered television journalism in 1994 as Political Editor of New Delhi Television ([[NDTV]]). He was the Managing Editor of both NDTV 24X7 and NDTV India and was responsible for overseeing the news policy for both. He hosted popular shows like ''The Big Fight'' at NDTV.

column1: He quit NDTV on 17 April 2005<ref>{{Cite web
column5: accessdate=18 December 2019}}</ref> to start his own company, [[Global Broadcast News]] (GBN), in collaboration with the American giant CNN and [[Raghav Bahl]]'s [[TV18]].<ref name=\"auto\" /> The latter broadcasts the Indian Edition (in English) of [[CNBC]] called CNBC-TV18, the Hindi consumer channel, [[CNBC Awaaz]] and an international channel, SAW. The new channel with Sardesai as the Editor-in-Chief was named [[CNN-IBN]]. It went on air on 17 December 2005. [[Global Broadcast News
column6: Channel 7]] has also come under this umbrella after Sardesai's company bought a 46 percent stake in the channel. Channel 7 was later renamed IBN7.

column1: On 29 May 2014, [[Reliance Industries Ltd]] announced it would be acquiring control in Network 18 Media & Investments Ltd, the parent of CNN-IBN, IBN7 and CNBC-TV18.<ref>{{cite web
column4: publisher=}}</ref> The board of RIL approved funding of up to {{INRConvert
column6: b}} to Independent Media Trust (IMT), of which RIL is the sole beneficiary, for acquisition of control in Network 18 and its subsidiaries.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=RIL to acquire control of Network 18, Rajdeep may go
column10: publisher=}}</ref> Subsequently, on 1 July 2014,Rajdeep,editor-in-chief of CNN IBN along with the entire founding team - editorial and managerial - resigned from the [[Network18]] group.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Full text: Rajdeep Sardesai's farewell letter to IBN network - Firstpost

column1: Sardesai and others were acquitted by a Hyderabad court in November 2019 after issuing an unconditional apology to IPS officer Rajiv Trivedi for false reporting on Sohrabuddin's alleged encounter killing case.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Rajdeep Sardesai, ors acquitted after issuing unconditional apology for false reporting on Sohrabuddin case
column5: work=Bar and Bench - Indian Legal news

column8: access-date=23 May 2018}}</ref> Rajdeep and Sagarika have two children, son Ishan, and daughter Tarini.<ref>{{cite news

column15: publisher=}}</ref> He was the Editor-in-Chief of [[Global Broadcast News]], that included [[CNN-IBN]], IBN7 and [[IBN-Lokmat]]; he resigned in July 2014.

column1: Sardesai was born in [[Ahmedabad]], [[Gujarat]] to a [[Goans
column3: Gujarati]] mother.<ref name=mc /> His father, [[Dilip Sardesai]], was a former Indian [[Test cricket]]er and his mother, Nandini, is an activist in [[Mumbai]] and former head of the Department of Sociology at [[St. Xavier's College, Mumbai]].<ref name=mc /> He completed his schooling up to [[Indian Certificate of Secondary Education
column5: Campion School]] in Mumbai, did two years of [[Indian School Certificate
column6: ISC]] in [[The Cathedral & John Connon School]], Mumbai, and completed a bachelor's course in economics from [[St. Xavier's College, Mumbai
column7: St. Xavier's College]]. He then went to [[University College, Oxford]], earning the degrees of [[Master of Arts (Oxbridge)
column8: Master of Arts]], and [[Bachelor of Laws]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070119190811/http://www.theindusview.com/issue3/people.html Cached version of ''Indus View'' 2.1 (January 2006)] The degree of Bachelor of Laws (LLB) is not awarded by Oxford University and here is a mistake for Bachelor of Civil Law (BCL), a postgraduate degree in law. All Bachelors of Arts and of Fine Art upon commencing their twenty-first term from matriculation may supplicate for the degree of Master of Arts Rajdeep Gupta</ref>

column1: While at Oxford he made six [[first-class cricket]] appearances for [[Oxford University Cricket Club
column2: Oxford University]] and one for a combined Oxford and [[Cambridge University Cricket Club
column3: Cambridge]] side against the [[Pakistani cricket team in England in 1987
column8: accessdate = 21 April 2013}}</ref> He was awarded a cricket [[Blue (university sport)
column11: title=Q&A: Dhoni is the hero of my 'Democracy's XI' - Rajdeep Sardesai

column1: Sardesai worked with ''[[The Times of India]]'' for six years, after joining it in October 1988,<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title='A new dawn in Indian cricket': Remembering Sachin Tendulkar's iconic Ranji Trophy debut
column7: accessdate=18 December 2019}}</ref> and was the city editor of its Mumbai edition. He entered television journalism in 1994 as Political Editor of New Delhi Television ([[NDTV]]). He was the Managing Editor of both NDTV 24X7 and NDTV India and was responsible for overseeing the news policy for both. He hosted popular shows like ''The Big Fight'' at NDTV.

column1: He quit NDTV on 17 April 2005<ref>{{Cite web
column5: accessdate=18 December 2019}}</ref> to start his own company, [[Global Broadcast News]] (GBN), in collaboration with the American giant CNN and [[Raghav Bahl]]'s [[TV18]].<ref name=\"auto\" /> The latter broadcasts the Indian Edition (in English) of [[CNBC]] called CNBC-TV18, the Hindi consumer channel, [[CNBC Awaaz]] and an international channel, SAW. The new channel with Sardesai as the Editor-in-Chief was named [[CNN-IBN]]. It went on air on 17 December 2005. [[Global Broadcast News
column6: Channel 7]] has also come under this umbrella after Sardesai's company bought a 46 percent stake in the channel. Channel 7 was later renamed IBN7.

column1: On 29 May 2014, [[Reliance Industries Ltd]] announced it would be acquiring control in Network 18 Media & Investments Ltd, the parent of CNN-IBN, IBN7 and CNBC-TV18.<ref>{{cite web
column4: publisher=}}</ref> The board of RIL approved funding of up to {{INRConvert
column6: b}} to Independent Media Trust (IMT), of which RIL is the sole beneficiary, for acquisition of control in Network 18 and its subsidiaries.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=RIL to acquire control of Network 18, Rajdeep may go
column10: publisher=}}</ref> Subsequently, on 1 July 2014,Rajdeep,editor-in-chief of CNN IBN along with the entire founding team - editorial and managerial - resigned from the [[Network18]] group.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Full text: Rajdeep Sardesai's farewell letter to IBN network - Firstpost

column1: Sardesai and others were acquitted by a Hyderabad court in November 2019 after issuing an unconditional apology to IPS officer Rajiv Trivedi for false reporting on Sohrabuddin's alleged encounter killing case.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Rajdeep Sardesai, ors acquitted after issuing unconditional apology for false reporting on Sohrabuddin case
column5: work=Bar and Bench - Indian Legal news

[[Category:Recipients of the Padma Shri in literature & education]]
'''''Lil' Romeo''''' is the self-titled debut [[studio album]] by [[United States
column3: Lil' Romeo]]. It was released July 3, 2001 on [[No Limit Records]], Soulja Music and [[Priority Records]]. The album has feature productions by Master P, Carlos Stephens and Sean \"Barney\" Thomas, the album also has guest appearances by Freequan, [[Silkk the Shocker]],  [[Lil' Zane]], [[Allusion]], Little D, 6 Piece and Afficial.

column1: The album garnered mixed reviews from music critics. It spawned two [[Single (music)
column3: My Baby]]\" and \"[[The Girlies]]\". The album debuted at number 6 on the ''Billboard'' 200 and was certified gold by the RIAA in 3 weeks.

column1: ''Lil' Romeo'' received a mixed reception from [[Music journalism
column2: music critics]]. [[AllMusic]] editor Jason Birchmeier praised the album for its \"great pop-rap productions\" and credited Master P for providing hooks that grabbed your attention.<ref name=\"AM\"/> Music critic [[Robert Christgau]] gave the album a two-star honorable mention, indicating a \"likable effort consumers attuned to its overriding aesthetic or individual vision may well enjoy.\"<ref>{{cite web
column8: accessdate=January 10, 2018}}</ref> He highlighted \"My Baby\" and \"Where They At\" as \"gangsta pop at its funniest, sickest, and safest.\"<ref name=\"Christgau\"/> Kathryn McGuire of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' commented on how the album was like a creation that Master P made in between his various business projects.<ref name=\"RS\"/> An editor from ''[[HipHopDX]]'' criticized the album for its repetitive material in the songs and Romeo's flow for being \"lackluster and underdeveloped.\"<ref name=\"HHDX\"/>

column1: The album proved to be a huge success, peaking at number 6 on the [[Billboard 200
column2: ''Billboard'' 200]] and number 5 on the [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]], selling well over 200,000 copies the 1st week<ref>{{cite magazine
column4: title=D12 Leapfrogs Keys, Returns To No.1
column11: accessdate=May 14, 2015}}</ref> and spawned the hit single \"[[My Baby (Lil' Romeo song)
column12: My Baby]]\", which made it to number 3 on the [[Billboard Hot 100
column13: ''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and number one on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]] music charts. The album was certified Gold by the RIAA selling over 500,000 copies in the United States of America on  August 8, 2001.<ref>{{cite web

column1: The album has been reported to have sold close to 2,000,000 copies in the United States to date.<ref name=\"Romeo biography\">{{cite web

column2: note5 = featuring [[Silkk the Shocker]] & Little D
title9 = I Want to Be Like You
title10 = Little Souljas Need Love Too

*\"That's Kool (Remix)\" contains a sample of \"Stick'em\" by [[The Fat Boys]]<ref name=\"Liner\"/>
*\"Make You Dance\" contains samples of \"[[Angel of the Morning]]\" by [[Chip Taylor]] and \"[[That's the Way (I Like It)]]\" by [[KC and the Sunshine Band]]<ref name=\"Liner\"/>
*\"Little Souljas Need Love Too\" contains a sample of \"[[Teenage Love (song)
*\"When I Get Grown\" contains samples of \"[[Love T.K.O.]]\" by [[Teddy Pendergrass]] and \"[[Back in the Day (Ahmad song)
*\"What\" contains a sample of \"[[What Y'all Want]] (Remix)\" by [[Eve (rapper)
*\"Take My Pain Away\" contains a sample of \"[[Take My Breath Away]]\" by [[Berlin (band)

Spelling correction; redirect bypass fromSpanish FlutoSpanish fluusingpopups,safe,Wbm1058,"This section of the [[Timeline of United States history]] concerns events from '''1900 to 1929'''.
*1900 – [[U.S. presidential election, 1900]]: [[William McKinley]] reelected president; [[Theodore Roosevelt]] elected vice president
*1901 – President McKinley begins second term, Theodore Roosevelt becomes Vice President
*1901 – President McKinley assassinated, Vice President Roosevelt becomes the 26th President
*1903 – The [[Wright brothers]] make their first powered flight in the ''[[Wright Flyer]]'' at [[Kitty Hawk, North Carolina]]
*1904 – [[U.S. presidential election, 1904]]: [[Theodore Roosevelt]] elected president for full term; [[Charles W. Fairbanks]] elected vice president
*1905 – President Roosevelt begins full term, Charles W. Fairbanks becomes Vice President
*1906 – [[Pure Food and Drug Act]] and [[Meat Inspection Act]]
*1906 – Theodore Roosevelt negotiates [[Treaty of Portsmouth]], receives [[Nobel Peace Prize]]

column3: Teddy Roosevelt, the Bull Moose, led American progressives in the early 20th century]]

column2: Coal mine explodes in Monongah, West Virginia]], killing at least 361. Worst industrial accident in American history.

column1: *1908 – [[U.S. presidential election, 1908]]: [[William Howard Taft]] elected president; [[James S. Sherman]] vice president. [[William Jennings Bryan]] loses for the third and final time.

column2: U.S. penny]] is changed to the [[Abraham Lincoln]] design

column1: *1909 – William Howard Taft becomes the 27th President, James S. Sherman becomes Vice President
*1909 – [[Robert Peary]] claims to have reached the [[North Pole]]
*1909 – [[NAACP]] founded by [[W. E. B. Du Bois]]
*1911 – First [[Indianapolis 500]] is staged; [[Ray Harroun]] is the first winner
*1912 – [[Girl Scouts of the USA]] was started by Juliette Gordon Low
*1912 – [[Theodore Roosevelt]] shot, but not killed, while campaigning for the bull Moose Party
*1912 – [[U.S. presidential election, 1912]]: [[Woodrow Wilson]] elected president, [[Thomas R. Marshall]], vice president. Roosevelt becomes the only [[third party (United States)
column2: third party]] candidate to come in second for well over a century.

column1: *1913 – Wilson becomes the 28th President and Marshall, Vice President

column2: woman suffrage parade]] in Washington D.C. is organized by [[Alice Paul]]

column1: *1913 – [[Sixteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution
*1913 – The [[Armory Show]] opens in New York City introducing [[Modern art]] both American and European to the American public.
*1913 – [[Seventeenth Amendment to the United States Constitution
column2: 17th Amendment]], establishing direct election of U.S. Senators.

column1: *1914 – [[Mother's Day]] established as a national holiday
*1916 – [[Jeannette Rankin]] first woman elected to U.S. congress
*1916 – [[Louis Brandeis]] appointed to [[Supreme Court of the United States

column3: Marshall]] reelected by a mere 3,773 votes in California

column1: *1917 – President Wilson and Vice President Marshall begin second terms

*1917–1919 – [[Silent Sentinels]] hold a vigil outside the White House gates in favor of women's suffrage, a nearly two-and-a-half year demonstration organized by [[Alice Paul]] and the [[National Woman's Party]]
*1917–1920 – [[First Red Scare]], marked by a widespread fear of Bolshevism and anarchism
*1918 – President Wilson's [[Fourteen Points]], which assures citizens that the Great War was being fought for a moral cause and for postwar peace in Europe
*1918 – Republicans win back congress in the Midterm elections.
*1918 – Armistice agreement ends World War I
*1919 – [[Treaty of Versailles]] agreed to by victorious powers.
*1919 – President Wilson has massive stroke. First Lady [[Edith Wilson]] takes over in a \"silent coup\".
*1919 – [[United States Senate]] rejects [[Treaty of Versailles]] and [[League of Nations]]
*1919 – [[Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution
column2: 18th Amendment]], establishing [[Prohibition in the United States
that year's World Series]], with the fallout lasting for decades

column1: *1920 – [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution
column2: 19th Amendment]], grants women the right to vote

column1: *1920 – [[U.S. presidential election, 1920]]: [[Warren G. Harding]] elected president, and [[Calvin Coolidge]]  vice president.
*1921 – Harding becomes the 29th President and Coolidge Vice President
*1923 – President Harding dies; Vice President Coolidge becomes the 30th President
*1924 – [[J. Edgar Hoover]] is appointed director of the [[Bureau of Investigation]] — predecessor to the [[FBI]].
*1924 – [[U.S. presidential election, 1924]]: [[Calvin Coolidge]] elected president for a full term, [[Charles G. Dawes]] elected vice president
*1925 – President Coolidge begins full term, Charles G. Dawes becomes Vice President

*1925 – [[Scopes Trial]], whose outcome found that the teaching of evolution in the classroom \"does not violate church and state or state religion laws but instead, merely prohibits the teaching of evolution on the grounds of intellectual disagreement\"

column2: WSM]] broadcasts the [[Grand Ole Opry]] for the first time.

column1: *1926 – [[NBC]] founded as the U.S.'s first major broadcast network
*1927 – [[Sacco and Vanzetti]] executed, seven years after they were convicted of murdering two men during an armed robbery in Massachusetts

column2: motion picture with sound]], is released

column1: *1927 – U.S. citizenship granted to inhabitants of [[U.S. Virgin Islands]]

column2: Columbia Broadcasting System]] (later called CBS) was founded, becomes second national radio network in the U.S.

column1: *1928 – Disney's ''[[Steamboat Willie]]'' opens, the first animated picture to feature [[Mickey Mouse]]
*1928 – [[Amelia Earhart]] becomes the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean.
*1928 – [[U.S. presidential election, 1928]]: [[Herbert C. Hoover]] elected president and [[Charles Curtis]] vice president
*1929 – Herbert C. Hoover becomes the 31st President, Charles Curtis becomes the Vice President
*1929 – The [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]] plummets a record 68 points over a two-day period, setting off the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929]] and triggering the [[Great Depression]]
*1929 – The [[Museum of Modern Art]] (MOMA) opens to the public in New York City
*1929 – [[American Samoa]] officially becomes a U.S. territory

column2: Punjabi]] documentary filmmaker and journalist, known for his activism through social action documentaries on topics such as agricultural labour, mass movements, human rights, environmentalism, Sufi tradition and Punjabi scholars.<ref name=\"Tribune India 2\">{{cite news
column8: date=30 June 2013}}</ref> Being dissatisfied with how [[Punjab]] was being depicted in films, he strives to portray the reality of Punjabi culture from \"an insider's point of view.\"<ref>{{cite news
column10: title='I Want to Portray the Real Punjab'

column1: The documentary films he has made include ''Born in Debt'', ''Zulm Aur Aman'', ''Karsewa: a different story'', ''Anhad Baja Bajey'', ''Not Every Time'', and ''Seva'',<ref name=\"Sikh Art and Film Foundation\">{{cite news
column8: date=2009}}</ref> and he co-wrote the 2014 Punjabi film ''Sarsa''.<ref>{{cite news
column14: date=19 March 2013}}</ref> He has written two articles for the ''[[Outlook India
column18: title=Scoot! Sherry Paaji Is in Da House

column1: and his latest project is a film based on the [[1915 Singapore Mutiny]].<ref name=\"Times of India 2\"/><ref name=\"Indian Express 1\"/>

He has a master's degree in Ancient Indian History, Archaeology and Culture, and a Masters in [[Mass Communications]]. He has worked on a number of independent films and has created documentaries dealing with social issues and politics of northern India. In the past, he has worked as an assistant editor for the newspaper ''[[Punjabi Tribune]]'',<ref name=\"Sikh Art and Film Foundation\"/> and has worked as editorial consultant for ''Day & Night News''.<ref>http://www.dayandnightnews.com/ {{Webarchive
column3: date=14 April 2010 }} Day & Night News</ref> and ''Global Punjab TV'', a Punjabi channel broadcast in the US and Canada. He also volunteers for Panjab Digital Library as Director, Communications.<ref name=\"The Hindu 2\">{{cite news

column1: Speaking about non-fiction films, Daljit Ami says:

column2: \"In our region where people have little interest in non-fiction, documentaries lose the race to entertainment. The dictum is 'nacho, gaao, socho mat', while documentaries demand that you to think.\" – Daljit Ami<ref name=\"Tribune India 3\">{{cite news

column1: In speaking toward film length, he says:

column2: \"The only problem with making short films is that the concept does not appeal to the larger audience and that they fail to generate any revenue.\" – Daljit Ami<ref>{{cite news

column1: Daljit Ami's Punjabi adaption of the book ''Roll of Honour'' which was authored in English by [[Amandeep Sandhu]], and is based on the events that happened post 1984 in Punjab, as \"Gwah De Fanah Hon To Pehlan\", was released in November 2014.
* ''Sudarshan: An Institution Of Simplicity'' (2002)<ref name=\"Tribune India 1\"/>

column4: title=On a Path Less Troden: Daljit Ami

column1: * ''Seva'' (2013)<ref name=\"Hindustan Times 1\"/><ref name=\"The Hindu 1\"/><ref name=\"Tribune India 4\"/>
* ''Singapore Mutiny of 1915'' (2014)<ref name=\"Times of India 2\"/><ref name=\"Indian Express 1\">{{cite news
''[[Times of India]]'' noted how the film ''Zulm Aur Aman'', with its song \"Zulm Rahe Aur Aman Bhi Ho\" by Pakistani singer Naseebo, made comparisons between [[Adolf Hitler]], [[George H. W. Bush
column2: George Bush]] and [[Tony Blair]], and illustrated how war-making can be a profitable enterprise for those that conduct it.<ref name=\"Times of India 1\">{{cite news
column5: title=Video brings out profit factor in wars

column1: ''[[Tribune India]]'' referred to ''Unearthing Unfamiliar'', a film on [[Sikh]] scholar Professor Pritam Singh and ''Sudarshan: An Institution Of Simplicity'', a film about a human rights activist, as path-breaking documentaries.<ref name=\"Tribune India 1\">{{cite news

''[[OhMyNews]]'' praised ''Not Every Time'', writing it \"superbly portrays the ongoing struggle of thousands of rural people who leave their green fields and countryside homes to march in the streets of different towns and cities of Punjab.\"<ref name=\"OhMyNews 1\">{{cite news

In an interview with \" Sikh Chic\" Daljit has stated his reason for translating the novel Roll Of Honour : \"Punjabi has its own texture and diversity of dialects. I thought that it would give me a chance to do something more {{sic
column2: then}} just translation. This invitation was too big to resist. I thought that it would be a liberating experience, which it turned out to be.\"<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Roll of Honour: An Interview With Author Amandeep Singh Sandhu, and Punjabi Translator Daljit Ami

column1: ''[[Hindustan Times]]'' spoke toward ''Seva'' and its being centred on history and [[Punjabi culture
column2: Punjabi]] heritage conservationist Namita Jaspal as its narrative makes comparisons between the present and the past, and instructs that the present is built upon the past.<ref name=\"Hindustan Times 1\">{{cite news
column13: df=dmy }}</ref>  ''[[The Hindu]]'' wrote \"It took Daljit Ami, an independent film maker from Punjab to discover that as a result of varied interpretations of 'sewa' in the context of Sikhism, not just the preservers but destroyers of precious heritage in Punjab draw upon 'sewa' to justify their deeds.\"<ref name=\"The Hindu 1\">{{cite news
column20: date=27 May 2013}}</ref>  ''Tribune India'' wrote the film \"not only underlines the significance of preserving heritage, but also salutes the contribution of those devoted to the onerous task of conserving.\"<ref name=\"Tribune India 4\">{{cite news

column1: ''Times of India'' spoke toward Daljit Ami's current project on the 1915 Singapore Mutiny and his research involving his visiting the historic locations involved.<ref name=\"Times of India 2\">{{cite news
column4: title=Haryana boys led first mutiny of World War I

column1: In preserving Punjab's history and culture, ''Zulm Aur Aman'' has been archived in the [[Jalandhar]]'s Desh Bhagat Yadgar Hall.<ref>{{cite news

column2: Punjabi]] documentary filmmaker and journalist, known for his activism through social action documentaries on topics such as agricultural labour, mass movements, human rights, environmentalism, Sufi tradition and Punjabi scholars.<ref name=\"Tribune India 2\">{{cite news
column8: date=30 June 2013}}</ref> Being dissatisfied with how [[Punjab]] was being depicted in films, he strives to portray the reality of Punjabi culture from \"an insider's point of view.\"<ref>{{cite news
column10: title='I Want to Portray the Real Punjab'

column1: The documentary films he has made include ''Born in Debt'', ''Zulm Aur Aman'', ''Karsewa: a different story'', ''Anhad Baja Bajey'', ''Not Every Time'', and ''Seva'',<ref name=\"Sikh Art and Film Foundation\">{{cite news
column8: date=2009}}</ref> and he co-wrote the 2014 Punjabi film ''Sarsa''.<ref>{{cite news
column14: date=19 March 2013}}</ref> He has written two articles for the ''[[Outlook India
column18: title=Scoot! Sherry Paaji Is in Da House

column1: and his latest project is a film based on the [[1915 Singapore Mutiny]].<ref name=\"Times of India 2\"/><ref name=\"Indian Express 1\"/>

He has a master's degree in Ancient Indian History, Archaeology and Culture, and a Masters in [[Mass Communications]]. He has worked on a number of independent films and has created documentaries dealing with social issues and politics of northern India. In the past, he has worked as an assistant editor for the newspaper ''[[Punjabi Tribune]]'',<ref name=\"Sikh Art and Film Foundation\"/> and has worked as editorial consultant for ''Day & Night News''.<ref>http://www.dayandnightnews.com/ {{Webarchive
column3: date=14 April 2010 }} Day & Night News</ref> and ''Global Punjab TV'', a Punjabi channel broadcast in the US and Canada. He also volunteers for Panjab Digital Library as Director, Communications.<ref name=\"The Hindu 2\">{{cite news

column1: Speaking about non-fiction films, Daljit Ami says:

column2: \"In our region where people have little interest in non-fiction, documentaries lose the race to entertainment. The dictum is 'nacho, gaao, socho mat', while documentaries demand that you to think.\" – Daljit Ami<ref name=\"Tribune India 3\">{{cite news

column1: In speaking toward film length, he says:

column2: \"The only problem with making short films is that the concept does not appeal to the larger audience and that they fail to generate any revenue.\" – Daljit Ami<ref>{{cite news

column1: Daljit Ami's Punjabi adaption of the book ''Roll of Honour'' which was authored in English by [[Amandeep Sandhu]], and is based on the events that happened post 1984 in Punjab, as \"Gwah De Fanah Hon To Pehlan\", was released in November 2014.

column1: *2× VFA/VFL premiership coach: [[2011 VFL Grand Final

'''Gary James Ayres''' (born 28 September 1960) is a former [[Australian rules football]]er who played for the [[Hawthorn Football Club]]. He is currently the senior coach for the [[Port Melbourne Football Club]] in the [[Victorian Football League]] (VFL).
Beginning his football career with Hawthorn in 1978, he had an illustrious career spanning from 1978–1993, playing 269 games and booting 70 goals.{{cn

He was part of a total of 5 premiership teams – 1983, 1986, 1988, 1989, and 1991.  He won the [[Norm Smith Medal]] twice, adjudged best on ground in 1986 and 1988 and is one of only three players in the history of the AFL to do so.{{cn
Ayres captained Victoria against Tasmania in the 1989 State of Origin contest.{{cn
He captained the Hawks in his final two years from 1992–1993.{{cn
Gary played most of his football in defence, particular the [[back pocket]] position. He was nicknamed \"[[Conan the Barbarian
column2: Conan]]\" by fans in reference to his powerful upper-body physique.  He used his body to good effect in body on body contested situations. Ayres' height and weight was 187 cm / 100 kg. [[Allan Jeans]] described Ayres as \"a good driver in heavy traffic\"<ref>{{cite web

column1: :<ref>[https://afltables.com/afl/stats/players/G/Gary_Ayres.html Gary Ayres' player profile at AFL Tables]</ref>
After retiring, Ayres turned to coaching; starting as an assistant coach to [[Malcolm Blight]] at [[Geelong Football Club
column2: Geelong]]. After Blight's resignation in 1994 (following Geelong's Grand Final defeat to the [[West Coast Eagles
column3: Eagles]]), Ayres was appointed senior coach for the 1995 AFL season. In his first year, the Cats lost to Carlton in the Grand Final (their fourth Grand Final defeat in seven seasons) by 61 points. In 1999, at the end of a disappointing season (Geelong finished 11th) and following the Geelong board's refusal to offer him a contract extension beyond the 2000 AFL season, Ayres quit as Geelong coach to take the coaching position at [[Adelaide Football Club
column4: Adelaide]] where Malcolm Blight had, again, just resigned.

column1: Ayres coached Adelaide from 2000 until 2004. When told he would not continue as coach for the 2005 season, Ayres quit midseason. Though he had been given the opportunity to stay for the rest of season 2004, he told the Adelaide board that if he could not coach the following year, he would leave immediately. He then walked out of the club's office without shaking hands or responding to media enquiries.{{cn
column2: date=August 2018}} He left Adelaide with a 55–52 win-loss ratio. He was replaced by [[Neil Craig]], who coached for the remainder of season 2004 and was eventually employed full-time.

column1: In 2006 he returned to coaching as [[assistant coach]] at the [[Essendon Football Club]], alongside veteran [[Kevin Sheedy (Australian footballer)
column2: Kevin Sheedy]]. When [[Matthew Knights]] was appointed as senior coach of Essendon at the end of the 2007 season, Knights vowed to modernise the club's support staff, Ayres subsequently lost his position as assistant coach.<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,22527600-11088,00.html Herald Sun: Knights cleans out assistants Gary Ayres, Dean Wallis]</ref>

column1: In 2008, Ayres was appointed senior coach of the [[Port Melbourne Football Club]] in the [[Victorian Football League]]. Ayres has coached at Port Melbourne continuously since then, with his current contract set to expire at the end of 2017, and he is the longest-serving coach in the club's history. Ayres has coached Port Melbourne to two premierships and three minor premierships, which included the club's perfect [[2011 VFL season
column2: 2011 season]], in which the club won all 21 of its premiership matches.<ref>{{cite web

column1: On 24 October 2000, Ayres was awarded the [[Australian Sports Medal]] for contribution to Australian Football.<ref>{{cite web
column4: publisher=[[Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (Australia)
column5: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet]]

column1: In 2005 Ayres spent the year in the media on [[Fox Footy Channel]]. Prior to that he also had a stint on [[Seven Network
{{1990 Victoria 2nd XVIII State of Origin players}}
[[Category:Recipients of the Australian Sports Medal]]","{{short description

The [[suffix]] '''-land''' which can be found in several countries' name and country subdivisions indicates a [[toponymy]]—a [[Terrestrial ecoregion
column2: land]]. The word came via [[Germanic languages

column1: Below is the list of places that ends with \"-land\" or \"Land\".
* [[List of islands of the United Kingdom]]
* [[List of islands of the United States]]
* [[Bjarmaland]], today comprise a part of Russia
* \"Lands\" of [[Antarctica]] (e.g. [[Queen Maud Land]], [[Marie Byrd Land]]) – see [[Geography of Antarctica]] for further examples
* [[List of islands]] - which technically ends with the \"-land\" from the word [[island]]

'''Marvi Sirmed''' (born 11 June 1970) is a [[Pakistani]] political commentator, journalist, and human rights activist and child raper and Anti Islamic thought provoking woman. She is Mentally Sick and retarded<ref>{{Cite web
Marvi Sirmed was born in [[Sialkot]], Punjab, Pakistan on 11 June 1970.<ref name=\":7\">{{Cite web
column3: title='Hijab is Still a Shit' Marvi Sirmed
column7: access-date=2020-03-16}}</ref> Her paternal family was agriculturist from Bhawalpur.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web
column9: title=Shocking History You Don't Know About Marvi Sirmed
column14: access-date=2020-03-16}}</ref> Her father, Chaudhry Anwar ul Haq, was Directorate General of Public Relations Punjab until 2003. In her childhood she accompanied her mother in women's protests.<ref>{{Cite web
column16: title=Marvi Sirmed Reflects on Future of Pakistan @TAG TV

column1: Before entering teaching and journalism careers she was a sciences student.<ref name=\":4\" /> She was a [[pre-med]] student and obtained her masters degree in science and education from the [[University of the Punjab
column2: University of Punjab]] and taught at secondary schools in [[Lahore]].<ref name=\":4\" /><ref name=\":7\" />

column1: Sirmed is a social democrat, advocating for secular polity and minority rights in Pakistan.<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2020-03-16}}</ref> She has advocated for improved [[domestic violence]] legislation<ref>{{Cite news
column7: title=Time to pass the domestic violence bill – The Express Tribune
column13: title='Beating up women still not a crime'

column1: In 1990s, Sirmed started getting involved in NGO activities along with her journalistic activities.<ref name=\":4\" /> In 2001–2002 she joined the Aurat Foundation's Legislative Watch Programme.<ref name=\":7\" /><ref name=\":5\" /> In 2004, she worked for The [[United Nations Development Programme]] in Pakistan, and simultaneously with the [[National Commission on the Status of Women]], Federal Ministry of Women’s Development, and the [[Parliament of Pakistan]].{{cn
Marvi Sirmed received the National Human Rights Award of the government of Pakistan in 2010 and Friend of the Parliament Award in 2012.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Marvi Sirmed – NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR DEMOCRACY
column5: access-date=2020-03-16}}</ref> Sirmed was a member of the executive council of the [[Human Rights Commission of Pakistan]] and serves as board chair of Bytes for All.<ref name=\":3\" /> She is fellow at [[National Endowment for Democracy]].<ref name=\":3\" /> She has been a freelance journalist since 2016.<ref name=\":7\" />

column1: As an outspoken advocate for human rights and secular democracy, Sirmed has attracted controversy among conservatives. In November 2007 she was arrested when she protested [[2007 Pakistani state of emergency
column2: 2007 emergency]] declared in Pakistan by then military dictator [[Pervez Musharraf]].<ref name=\":5\" />

column1: When the United States Embassy in Pakistan invited LGBT people to an event, Sirmed's defense of their decision was met with attacks on [[YouTube]].<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite book
column11: language=en}}</ref> In another televised debate broadcast on YouTube, Sirmed again spoke in defense of LGBT rights, leading her to be threatened with both death and sexual violence.<ref name=\":0\"/> The Coalition for Women in Journalism (CFWIJ) condemned online misinformation spreading campaign concerning Sirmed.<ref name=\":8\">{{Cite web
column13: title=CFWIJ urges government to act after trolls now target Marvi Sirmed - Journalism Pakistan
column16: access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref> CFWIJ Founding Director Kiran Nazish complained that the amount of propaganda and harassment of women journalists in Pakistan was unprecedented, with many inciting violence against women journalists in general and Sirmed in particular.<ref name=\":8\" /> Senior journalist member of CFWIJ, Beena Sarwar, said that while social media can be put to good use, it is being misused for negative purposes that violate fundamental rights and human dignity.<ref name=\":8\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column18: title=CFWIJ condemns death threats to Marvi Sirmed - Pakistan Today

column1: In 2016, Sirmed appeared on a live television debate with conservative Islamic scholar and parliamentarian [[Hafiz Hamdullah]]. Their argument escalated, leading Hamdullah to threaten her. Later when Hamdullah's citizenship was challenged, she publicly supported him on the issue to criticize officials who saw a problem only with his citizenship and not with his other behavior.<ref name=\":4\" />

On 3 March 2020, during live TV debates on [[Neo News]], Sirmed interrupted [[Khalil-ur-Rehman Qamar]] with the chant \"[[Mera Jism Meri Marzi]]\" (\"My Body My Choice\"). Qamar called the slogan shameful and made derogatory misogynist  remarks about her and shamed her body which led to criticism and boycott of him by media fraternity.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Mahira Khan calls out Khalil Ur Rehman Qamar for his blatant misogyny
column13: title=Media production house suspends Khalil ur Rehman Qamar
column23: title=Pakistan: Director Khalil-ur-Rehman abuses journalist Marvi Sirmed on air for supporting #AuratMarch2020

column1: Sirmed explained her position in interviews given to Daud Khattak and DW.com''.'' When asked whether \"[[My body, my choice
column2: my body my choice]]\" was priority for women of non-elite social classes, and whether \"my life\" might be better wording than \"my body,\" Sirmed retorted that \"my body, my choice\" is an issue relevant to Pakistani women across all classes, and that '“My body, my choice” means that no society can wage their wars at the expense of a woman's body. We ask the men not to use our bodies for their ''ghairat'' or honor. We ask them to stop killing us in the name of honor and give us the right to say no because we have the right to say no to anything that we don't feel comfortable with. We must have the right to say that we can't tolerate sexual harassment and to say no to decisions regarding our marriages by other [family members]. Our religion gives us the right to choose our life partner, so why not society?\"<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Pakistani Women's Rights Activist Sees Victory

column3: title=Journalist couple shot at in Pakistan, both unhurt
column11: title=Well-known Pakistani journalist Marvi Sirmed shot  at
column14: publisher=NDTV}}</ref> and again in 2018,<ref name=\"th1\">{{cite news
column16: title=Columnist Marvi Sarmad escapes attempt on life
column19: language=en}}</ref> she was shot at by unidentified gunmen and escaped unhurt. Her home has three times  been ransacked, with passports and documents being taken.<ref>{{Cite news
column22: title=Journalist Marvi Sirmed's home ransacked; electronic devices, travel documents stolen
column28: title=SAMC seeks probe into 'robbery' - The Express Tribune

Qamar called the slogan shameful and made derogatory misogynist  remarks about her and shamed her body which led to criticism and boycott of him by media fraternity.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Mahira Khan calls out Khalil Ur Rehman Qamar for his blatant misogyny
column13: title=Media production house suspends Khalil ur Rehman Qamar

column1: Sirmed explained her position in interviews given to Daud Khattak and DW.com''.'' When asked whether \"[[My body, my choice
column2: my body my choice]]\" was priority for women of non-elite social classes, and whether \"my life\" might be better wording than \"my body,\" Sirmed retorted that \"my body, my choice\" is an issue relevant to Pakistani women across all classes, and that '“My body, my choice” means that no society can wage their wars at the expense of a woman's body. We ask the men not to use our bodies for their ''ghairat'' or honor. We ask them to stop killing us in the name of honor and give us the right to say no because we have the right to say no to anything that we don't feel comfortable with. We must have the right to say that we can't tolerate sexual harassment and to say no to decisions regarding our marriages by other [family members]. Our religion gives us the right to choose our life partner, so why not society?\"<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Pakistani Women's Rights Activist Sees Victory

column3: title=Journalist couple shot at in Pakistan, both unhurt

column16: title=Columnist Marvi Sarmad escapes attempt on life
column19: language=en}}</ref> she was shot at by unidentified gunmen and escaped unhurt. Her home has three times  been ransacked, with passports and documents being taken.<ref>{{Cite news

column1: She is married to journalist Sirmed Manzoor.<ref name=\":1\" />

The '''Ornate Butterflyfish''', '''Chaetodon ornatissimus''', is a [[species]] of butterflyfish in the [[family]] ''Chaetodontidae'' and [[genus]] ''Chaetodon''. ''Chaetodon'' is a tropical fish genus which contains 87 species <ref name=\":0\">Froese, R. and D. Pauly. Editors. 2019. FishBase. World Wide Web electronic publication. www.fishbase.org, (2019)</ref>. ''Chaetodon'' is the largest genus in the family ''Chaetodontidae'' <ref name=\":0\" />.

''C. ornatissimus'' is commonly referred to as:  Clown Butterflyfish, Clown Butterfly, Coralfishes, Ornate Butterfly, Ornate Coralfish and Ornatissimus Butterfly. The Ornate Butterflyfish is a close relative of the [[Mailed butterflyfish
column2: Mailed Butterflyfish]] (''C. reticulatus'') and the [[Scrawled butterflyfish
column3: Scrawled Butterflyfish]] (''C. meyeri'') <ref name=\":1\">Fessler, Jennifer L., and Mark W. Westneat. \"Molecular phylogenetics of the butterflyfishes (Chaetodontidae): taxonomy and biogeography of a global coral reef fish family.\" ''Molecular phylogenetics and evolution'' 45.1 (2007): 50-68.</ref>. Together they make up the subgenus called “Citharoedus”, but as this name had already been used for the mollusk genus when it was given to the fish, it is not valid. They are probably quite close to the subgenus Corallochaetodon, which contains the [[Melon butterflyfish
column4: Melon Butterflyfish]] (''C. trifasciatus''). Like these, they might be separated into Megaprotodon if the [[genus]] ''[[Chaetodon]]'' is split up <ref name=\":1\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' is most easily identified by its color pattern which helps protect them from predators. Ornate butterflyfish have white bodies with orange to orange-brown oblique bands <ref name=\":0\" />. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head: one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout, and the tail has two black bars <ref name=\":0\" />. The size of the ornate butterflyfish ranges from 13-18 cm total length (mean +/- SD = 16.2 +/- 1.4 cm) and pair members are nearly always indistinguishable based on size <ref name=\":3\">Adam, T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour'', ''79''(6), 1183-1189.</ref>.
''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' adults are predominately found in pairs that occupy exclusive territories including Clearwater [[Lagoon
column2: lagoons]] and seaward reefs rich in coral growth (size range ~100-1400m2) <ref name=\":3\" />. On the other hand, juvenile ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' live in solitary, tend to be shy, and live in the arms of branching corals for protection <ref name=\":0\" />. Once juveniles reach breeding age, they form pairs <ref name=\":0\" />. It is uncommon to find adult ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'''  without a mate. Pairs also establish a \"home range\" where you will likely always find them <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' are monogamous and pair-forming coral reef fish. Many ornate butterflyfish mate for life. Spawning activity occurs at different times depending on each biome. Tropical spawning peaks in winter and early spring, while temperate spawning occurs in midsummer <ref name=\":7\">{{Cite web
column10: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>. Spawning occurs at dusk and eggs are released and fertilized in the water column <ref name=\":7\" />.

column1: The Ornate Butterflyfish is widespread throughout the [[Tropics
column2: tropical]] waters of the Indo-Pacific area ranging from [[Sri Lanka]] to [[Hawaii]], the [[Marquesas Islands
column3: Marquesas]], the [[Pitcairn Islands]], North to Southern [[Japan]], South to Lord Howe, and Rapa in the Austral Islands <ref>Hernández, Sebastián, et al. \"First Records of Striped Boarfish Evistias acutirostris and Ornate Butterflyfish Chaetodon ornatissimus from Easter Island1.\" ''Pacific Science'' 69.4 (2015): 525-529.</ref>. Over three-quraters of the world's fish species inhabit this region<ref>{{aut
column4: Hsu, Kui-Ching; Chen, Jeng-Ping & Shao, Kwang-Tsao}}(2007): Molecular phylogeny of ''Chaetodon''(Teleostei: Chaetodontidae) in the Indo-West Pacific: evolution in geminate species pairs and species groups. ''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'''''14''': 77–86.</ref>. The environment ''C. ornatissimus'' lives in is marine, inshore, tropical (30°N - 30°S, 77°E - 124°W) and reef associated <ref name=\":2\">Myers, R. F. (1991). ''Micronesian reef fishes''. Barrigada, Guam: Coral Graphics.</ref>. They tend to live at a depth range between 1-36 meters <ref name=\":2\" />.

column1: There are many natural and anthropogenic disruptions which play a major role in loss of habitat of organisms living in coral reef communities. Sessile, benthic communities on tropical coral reefs have natural disruptions including tropical storms, unseasonal temperature extremes and infestations of crown-of-thorn sea stars (''Acanthaster planci'')<ref name=\":5\">Pratchett, M. S., Wilson, S. K., & Baird, A. H. (2006). Declines in the abundance of Chaetodon butterflyfishes following extensive coral depletion. ''Journal of fish Biology'', ''69''(5), 1269-1280.</ref>. These events are becoming more frequent which makes anthropogenic influences more chronic. Anthropogenic disturbances include overfishing, pollution and coastal development all of which cause depletion in corals<ref name=\":5\" />. Over 30 percent of the coral reef communities in the world have already been degraded; however, by 2030 more than 60 percent of coral reef communities will have been lost<ref name=\":5\" />.

These changes in the structure of benthic coral reef habitats have adverse effects on coral reef fish, specifically butterflyfish. Several studies documented the decline of butterflyfish, and localized extinctions, following coral depletion. A study by Pratchett et. al., revealed declines in abundance of ''Chaetodon'' butterflyfish were almost certainly related to coral depletion<ref name=\":5\" />. Declines in abundances of butterflyfish were due to starvation<ref name=\":5\" />.

Another adverse anthropogenic effect which alters habitat community composition is the shift from coral-dominated to seaweed-dominated benthic communities. Anthropogenic impacts of overfishing of herbivorous fish and increase of eutrophication create favorable conditions for seaweed growthBrooker, R. M. ''et al.'' Cryptic effects of habitat declines: coral-associated fishes avoid coral-seaweed interactions due to visual and chemical cues. ''Sci. Rep.'' '''6''', 18842; doi: 10.1038/srep18842 (2016).. Increase in seaweed-dominated benthic communities’ limits expansion of coral colonies and availability of surfaces for larval settlement and development. Coral reef communities provide shelter, and food resources for Butterflyfish. However, the presence of seaweed has a substantial impact on butterflyfish, as they actively avoid corals in contact with seaweed.

''C. ornatissimus'' feed exclusively on coral polyp tissue and small organisms. Butterflyfish feed on ten different coral species, which is the broadest range of corals when compared with other coral-eating  butterflyfish species <ref name=\":4\">Collinske, G. (2017, August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki></ref>. Other obligate corallivores (coral-eating) butterflyfish species include: ''[[Blacktail butterflyfish
column15: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores, which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)
column18: Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells; therefore, butterflyfish need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral, and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake, sprint, turn and reverse <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' are one of the most popular tropical fishes with divers and aquarists <ref name=\":7\" />. However, ornate butterflyfish are nearly impossible to successfully keep in captivity because they are obligate corallivores <ref name=\":7\" />.
* Adam, T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour'', ''79''(6), 1183-1189.

*Collinske, G. (2017, August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki>

mountain range in Zimbabwe and Mozambique}}

column1: :''\"Eastern Highlands\" also refers to [[Eastern Highlands Province]] in Papua New Guinea, and part of the [[Great Dividing Range]], [[Australia]].''

column4: Northern part of the Eastern Highlands range as seen from Nyanga town.]]

column3: Eastern Highlands looking south towards Nyanga.]]
Mt. Mozi is a prominent peak at the Northern end of the range.]]

column1: The '''Eastern Highlands''', also known as the '''Manica Highlands''', is a [[mountain range]] on the border of [[Zimbabwe]] and [[Mozambique]]. The Eastern Highlands extend north and south for about {{convert
column4: mi}} through Zimbabwe's [[Manicaland Province]] and Mozambique's [[Manica Province]].<ref name=\"EnZim\">{{cite book

column1: The highlands consist of three main mountain groups – The Nyanga, Bvumba, and Chimanimani mountains - and several smaller ranges. The mountains are mostly sparsely populated, covered in rich grasslands, shrublands, woodlands and forests.<ref name=\"EnZim\" />

The [[Nyanga Mountains]] in the north contain Zimbabwe's highest mountain [[Mount Nyangani]] (2,592 m), and [[Mutarazi Falls]], Africa's second-longest waterfall. Zimbabwe's agricultural [[Honde Valley]] lies southeast of the Nyanga range, and leads into Mozambique.

[[Mutare]] is the largest city in the highlands. It is located on the Zimbabwean side of the Mutare Gap, a saddle between the Nyanga and Bvumba mountains. The main east-west road through the highlands is the [[R5 road (Zimbabwe)
column2: A3]] (Zimbabwe) - N6 (Mozambique), which connects the port of [[Beira, Mozambique
column3: Beira]] in Mozambique to Zimbabwe's capital [[Harare]] via [[Chimoio]], [[Manica, Mozambique
column4: Manica]], and Mutare, with a border crossing at [[Machipanda]]. The [[Beira–Bulawayo railway]] also crosses the highlands at Machipanda.

column1: The [[Bvumba Mountains]] are centrally situated south of [[Mutare]]. They lie mostly in Zimbabwe, but a northeastern spur, Monte Vumba, reaches into Mozambique. Agricultural [[Burma Valley]] lies south and east of the Bvumba Mountains.

South of Burma Valley, the Tsetsera, Gweni, and Tandara plateaus lie along the border, separated by east-west river valleys lying in fault rifts.<ref>Lister, L.A. (1987). \"The Erosion Surfaces of Zimbabwe\". Zimbabwe Geological Survey Bulletin #90.</ref><ref>Ghiurghi, Andrea & Dondeyne, S. & Bannerman, J.. (2010). Chimanimani national reserve: management plan. 10.13140/2.1.1734.6240.</ref>

The [[Chimanimani Mountains]] lie south of the Mussapa Pequeno River, which divides them from the Tandara plateau. The Chimanimani range consists of a high plateau with several ridges running north and south. [[Monte Binga]] on the border is the highest peak in Mozambique and the second-highest in Zimbabwe. Mussapa Gap is a pass through the mountains that follows the eastward-flowing Mussapa Grande River and westward-flowing Nyanyadzi River. Mussapa Gap was an important trade and migration route through the higlands for centuries.<ref>Ghiurghi, Andrea & Dondeyne, S. & Bannerman, J.. (2010). Chimanimani national reserve: management plan. 10.13140/2.1.1734.6240.</ref>

The Rusitu-Tanganda fault, an east-west rift that carries the eastward-flowing Rusitu River and the westward flowing Tanganda River, marks the southern end of the Chimanimani Mountains. A hilly upland extends south from the fault into Chipinge District, and the highest point is [[Mount Selinda]] at 1230 meters.<Mapure, Isaac (2012). \"Determinants of vegetation composition and diversity of a moist forest-savanna boundary in south-eastern Zimbabwe\". International Journal of Biodiversity and Conservation Vol. 4(14), pp. 584-591, November, 2012</ref>

The Eastern Highlands are part of the '''East African Highlands''', one of four distinct physiographic divisions on the African continent. The East African Highlands physiographic division consists of the [[East African Rift]] and [[Ethiopian Highlands
column2: Abyssinian]] physiographic provinces, part of the long chain of mountains that runs down [[East Africa]]. The mountains and mountain ranges that make up the East African Highlands share many common plant and animal species and communities, known as [[Afromontane]] flora and fauna.

column1: The Highlands have a more equable climate than Zimbabwe's central plateau, with higher rainfall, low cloud and heavy mists and dew as moisture moves inland from the [[Indian Ocean]]. Many streams and rivers originate in these mountains. The northern portion is drained by tributaries of the  [[Zambezi River]], while the southern portion is drained by tributaries of the [[Save River (Africa)
column2: Save River]].<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\">\"Eastern Zimbabwe montane forest-grassland mosaic\". World Wildlife Fund. Accessed 17 June 2018 [https://www.worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/at1006]</ref> The eastern slope is drained by Mozambique's [[Buzi River (Mozambique)
name = Eastern Zimbabwe montane forest-grassland mosaic
caption = North face of [[Monte Binga]] in the [[Chimanimani Mountains]]
map_caption = Map of the Eastern Zimbabwe montane forest-grassland mosaic

column1: The Highlands are home to the '''Eastern Zimbabwe montane forest-grassland mosaic''' [[ecoregion]]. The ecoregion includes the portion of the highlands above 1000 meters elevation, including the Inyangani Mountains, Bvumba Mountains, [[Chimanimani Mountains]], Chipinge Uplands, and the isolated [[Mount Gorongosa]] further east in Mozambique. The [[Southern Miombo woodlands]] ecoregion lies at lower elevations east and west of the highlands.<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\"/>

The highlands have a cooler, moister climate than the surrounding lowlands, which support distinct communities of plants and animals. The ecoregion is home to several plant communities: submontane and montane grasslands, moist evergreen forest, dry montane forest, miombo woodlands, and [[heathland]]s.<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\"/>

Much of the small area consists of rolling hills covered with grassland, which are renewed annually following the fires that occur at the end of the dry season. At lower elevations, ''[[Themeda triandra]]'' is the predominant grass on the more fertile red soils, and ''[[Loudetia simplex]]'' is common on less-fertile white sandy soils. At higher elevations are montane grasslands made up mostly of short, tufted grasses, including ''[[Loudetia simplex]], [[Trachypogon spicatus]], [[Exotheca abyssinica]],'' and ''[[Monocymbium ceresiiforme]]''.<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\"/>

Some valleys and east-facing slopes contain areas of tropical rainforest, with a high canopy, [[liana]]s, and a rich undergrowth. There are larger areas of dry forest at higher altitudes in places where the ground is well watered and on drier slopes patches of [[miombo]] woodland ''([[Brachystegia spiciformis]]'', ''[[Brachystegia tamarindoides]]'' and ''[[Uapaca kirkiana]]'') and areas of heathland at higher elevations. There are patches of the tall evergreen Mobola Plum ''[[Parinari curatellifolia]]'' near the town of [[Chipinge]] and on the western slopes of the Nyanga Highlands.
In the Chimanimani Mountains and [[Mount Gorongosa]], heathlands are found on poor, acidic sandy soils derived from [[quartzite]]. The heathlands are of two types, [[Ericaceae
column2: ericaceous]] and [[proteaceous]]. The ericaceous heathlands are dominated by ''Philippia pallidiflora, P. hexandra, Phylica ericoides, Passerina montana, Erica eylesii, E. pleiotricha, E. gazensis,'' and ''E. johnstoniana. Protea gazensis, P. welwitschii'', and ''[[Leucospermum saxosum]]'' are common in the proteaceous heathlands.<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\"/>

column1: A number of indigenous monocot lilies with small distribution ranges occur in the highlands. ''Cryptostephanotis vansonii'', ''Cyrtanthus rhodesianus'', and ''Scadoxus pole-evansi'' are popular with rare plant collectors.

This variety of different types of habitat results in a richness of animal life too. Animals found in the highlands include [[blue monkey]] ''(Cercopithecus mitis)'' [[Sykes' monkey]] ''(Cercopithecus albogularis)'', [[East African little collared fruit bat]] ''(Myonycteris relicta)'' and [[Marshall's pygmy chameleon]] ''([[Rhampholeon]] marshalli)''. Many of these animals are found throughout East Africa.<ref>{{WWF ecoregion

The highlands are also rich in birdlife<ref>Ian Sinclair, Birds of Southern Africa, Struik Publishers 1996</ref> including [[trumpeter hornbill]] ''(Bycanistes bucinator)'', [[Knysna turaco]] ''(Tauraco corythaix)'', [[purple-crested turaco]] ''(Tauraco porphyreolophus)'', [[crested guineafowl]] ''(Guttera pucherani)'' and [[crowned eagle]] ''(Stephanoaetus coronatus)''. Two species, the [[Chirinda apalis]] ''(Apalis chirindensis)'' and [[Roberts's warbler]] ''(Oreophilais robertsi)'', are endemic to the Eastern Highlands. The Chirinda apalis lives deep in the evergreen forests, while Roberts's warbler inhabits the forest edge.<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\"/>
The forests are also full of butterflies, most notably [[Papilio
column2: swallowtails]] such as the emperor swallowtail ''([[Papilio ophidicephalus]])'' and the citrus swallowtail ''([[Papilio demodocus]])'' and the forest undergrowth in particular shelters a variety of reptiles including [[skink]]s, [[gecko]]s, [[lizard]]s, [[frog]]s, [[toad]]s, and [[snake]]s.
Reptiles and frogs of the Eastern Highlands}}

column1: The mountain forests are vulnerable to logging and the grasslands susceptible to fire and the rainforests, which by definition grow on well-watered fertile land, to clearance for agriculture. The moist climate is ideal for planting tea, coffee and hardwoods. However, much of the original vegetation remains, especially at higher altitudes, which are not suitable for farming.

Large areas of the highlands are protected, including [[Nyanga National Park]] in the Nyanga Mountains, [[Bunga Forest Botanical Reserve]] in the Bvumba Mountains, and Zimbabwe's 171km<sup>2</sup> [[Chimanimani National Park]] and Mozambique's [[Chimanimani National Reserve]] in the Chimanimani Mountains. The Chimanimani park and reserve together form the core of the Chimanimani Transfrontier Conservation Area.

mountain range in Zimbabwe and Mozambique}}

column4: Northern part of the Eastern Highlands range as seen from Nyanga town.]]

column3: Eastern Highlands looking south towards Nyanga.]]
Mt. Mozi is a prominent peak at the Northern end of the range.]]

column1: The '''Eastern Highlands''', also known as the '''Manica Highlands''', is a [[mountain range]] on the border of [[Zimbabwe]] and [[Mozambique]]. The Eastern Highlands extend north and south for about {{convert
column4: mi}} through Zimbabwe's [[Manicaland Province]] and Mozambique's [[Manica Province]].<ref name=\"EnZim\">{{cite book

column1: The highlands consist of three main mountain groups – The Nyanga, Bvumba, and Chimanimani mountains - and several smaller ranges. The mountains are mostly sparsely populated, covered in rich grasslands, shrublands, woodlands and forests.<ref name=\"EnZim\" />

The [[Nyanga Mountains]] in the north contain Zimbabwe's highest mountain [[Mount Nyangani]] (2,592 m), and [[Mutarazi Falls]], Africa's second-longest waterfall. Zimbabwe's agricultural [[Honde Valley]] lies southeast of the Nyanga range, and leads into Mozambique.

[[Mutare]] is the largest city in the highlands. It is located on the Zimbabwean side of the Mutare Gap, a saddle between the Nyanga and Bvumba mountains. The main east-west road through the highlands is the [[R5 road (Zimbabwe)
column2: A3]] (Zimbabwe) - N6 (Mozambique), which connects the port of [[Beira, Mozambique
column3: Beira]] in Mozambique to Zimbabwe's capital [[Harare]] via [[Chimoio]], [[Manica, Mozambique
column4: Manica]], and Mutare, with a border crossing at [[Machipanda]]. The [[Beira–Bulawayo railway]] also crosses the highlands at Machipanda.

column1: The [[Bvumba Mountains]] are centrally situated south of [[Mutare]]. They lie mostly in Zimbabwe, but a northeastern spur, Monte Vumba, reaches into Mozambique. Agricultural [[Burma Valley]] lies south and east of the Bvumba Mountains.

South of Burma Valley, the Tsetsera, Gweni, and Tandara plateaus lie along the border, separated by east-west river valleys lying in fault rifts.<ref>Lister, L.A. (1987). \"The Erosion Surfaces of Zimbabwe\". Zimbabwe Geological Survey Bulletin #90.</ref><ref>Ghiurghi, Andrea & Dondeyne, S. & Bannerman, J.. (2010). Chimanimani national reserve: management plan. 10.13140/2.1.1734.6240.</ref>

The [[Chimanimani Mountains]] lie south of the Mussapa Pequeno River, which divides them from the Tandara plateau. The Chimanimani range consists of a high plateau with several ridges running north and south. [[Monte Binga]] on the border is the highest peak in Mozambique and the second-highest in Zimbabwe. Mussapa Gap is a pass through the mountains that follows the eastward-flowing Mussapa Grande River and westward-flowing Nyanyadzi River. Mussapa Gap was an important trade and migration route through the higlands for centuries.<ref>Ghiurghi, Andrea & Dondeyne, S. & Bannerman, J.. (2010). Chimanimani national reserve: management plan. 10.13140/2.1.1734.6240.</ref>

The Rusitu-Tanganda fault, an east-west rift that carries the eastward-flowing Rusitu River and the westward flowing Tanganda River, marks the southern end of the Chimanimani Mountains. A hilly upland extends south from the fault into Chipinge District, and the highest point is [[Mount Selinda]] at 1230 meters.

The Eastern Highlands are part of the '''East African Highlands''', one of four distinct physiographic divisions on the African continent. The East African Highlands physiographic division consists of the [[East African Rift]] and [[Ethiopian Highlands
column2: Abyssinian]] physiographic provinces, part of the long chain of mountains that runs down [[East Africa]]. The mountains and mountain ranges that make up the East African Highlands share many common plant and animal species and communities, known as [[Afromontane]] flora and fauna.

column1: The Highlands have a more equable climate than Zimbabwe's central plateau, with higher rainfall, low cloud and heavy mists and dew as moisture moves inland from the [[Indian Ocean]]. Many streams and rivers originate in these mountains. The northern portion is drained by tributaries of the  [[Zambezi River]], while the southern portion is drained by tributaries of the [[Save River (Africa)
column2: Save River]].<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\">\"Eastern Zimbabwe montane forest-grassland mosaic\". World Wildlife Fund. Accessed 17 June 2018 [https://www.worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/at1006]</ref> The eastern slope is drained by Mozambique's [[Buzi River (Mozambique)
name = Eastern Zimbabwe montane forest-grassland mosaic
caption = North face of [[Monte Binga]] in the [[Chimanimani Mountains]]
map_caption = Map of the Eastern Zimbabwe montane forest-grassland mosaic

column1: The Highlands are home to the '''Eastern Zimbabwe montane forest-grassland mosaic''' [[ecoregion]]. The ecoregion includes the portion of the highlands above 1000 meters elevation, including the Inyangani Mountains, Bvumba Mountains, [[Chimanimani Mountains]], Chipinge Uplands, and the isolated [[Mount Gorongosa]] further east in Mozambique. The [[Southern Miombo woodlands]] ecoregion lies at lower elevations east and west of the highlands.<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\"/>

The highlands have a cooler, moister climate than the surrounding lowlands, which support distinct communities of plants and animals. The ecoregion is home to several plant communities: submontane and montane grasslands, moist evergreen forest, dry montane forest, miombo woodlands, and [[heathland]]s.<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\"/>

Much of the small area consists of rolling hills covered with grassland, which are renewed annually following the fires that occur at the end of the dry season. At lower elevations, ''[[Themeda triandra]]'' is the predominant grass on the more fertile red soils, and ''[[Loudetia simplex]]'' is common on less-fertile white sandy soils. At higher elevations are montane grasslands made up mostly of short, tufted grasses, including ''[[Loudetia simplex]], [[Trachypogon spicatus]], [[Exotheca abyssinica]],'' and ''[[Monocymbium ceresiiforme]]''.<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\"/>

Some valleys and east-facing slopes contain areas of tropical rainforest, with a high canopy, [[liana]]s, and a rich undergrowth. There are larger areas of dry forest at higher altitudes in places where the ground is well watered and on drier slopes patches of [[miombo]] woodland ''([[Brachystegia spiciformis]]'', ''[[Brachystegia tamarindoides]]'' and ''[[Uapaca kirkiana]]'') and areas of heathland at higher elevations. There are patches of the tall evergreen Mobola Plum ''[[Parinari curatellifolia]]'' near the town of [[Chipinge]] and on the western slopes of the Nyanga Highlands.
In the Chimanimani Mountains and [[Mount Gorongosa]], heathlands are found on poor, acidic sandy soils derived from [[quartzite]]. The heathlands are of two types, [[Ericaceae
column2: ericaceous]] and [[proteaceous]]. The ericaceous heathlands are dominated by ''Philippia pallidiflora, P. hexandra, Phylica ericoides, Passerina montana, Erica eylesii, E. pleiotricha, E. gazensis,'' and ''E. johnstoniana. Protea gazensis, P. welwitschii'', and ''[[Leucospermum saxosum]]'' are common in the proteaceous heathlands.<ref name=\"worldwildlife.org\"/>

column1: '''''Great Western Valkyrie''''' is the fourth studio album by American rock band [[Rival Sons]]. The album, which is the first to feature new bass player Dave Beste (in place of founding member Robin Everhart), was released in June 2014.<ref>{{cite website
column6: accessdate=June 9, 2014}}</ref> It garnered positive reviews from critics who praised the band's musicianship in recapturing late 60s hard rock. ''Great Western Valkyrie'' peaked within the top 40 of countries like Finland, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and the UK, and spawned three [[Single (music)
column7: single]]s: \"Electric Man\", \"Open My Eyes\" and \"Good Things\". To promote the record, the band toured across Europe and North America with appearances at music festivals and talk shows.

column1: On April 14, 2014, the band announced that they planned four tour dates in the UK to promote ''Great Western Valkyrie'' on its release date, beginning with [[London]]'s [[Scala (club)
column2: Scala]] club and finishing at [[Manchester]]'s Gorilla club.<ref>{{cite magazine
column4: title=Exclusive: Rival Sons Announce UK Tour Dates
column10: accessdate=November 5, 2017}}</ref> On October 17, they made their UK television debut performing \"Electric Man\" on ''[[Later... with Jools Holland]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=BBC Two - Later... with Jools Holland, Series 45, Episode 5
column15: accessdate=November 9, 2017}}</ref> On December 17, they announced a 22-city spring 2015 tour in Europe,  starting at [[O2 Academy Leeds
column16: Leeds Academy]] in the UK and ending at the Schüür concert hall in [[Lucerne]], [[Switzerland]], with some appearances at music festivals like [[Monsters of Rock]].<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Rival Sons will tour Europe next year
column24: accessdate=November 5, 2017}}</ref> They followed that up with an 18-city North American tour, beginning with [[Toronto]]'s [[Phoenix Concert Theatre]] and finishing at [[Vancouver]]'s [[Commodore Ballroom]].<ref>{{cite magazine
column26: title=Rival Sons Unleash 'Electric Man' Video, Gear Up for Tour
column32: accessdate=November 9, 2017}}</ref> On September 10, 2015, they toured with [[Black Sabbath]] as one of the opening acts of their farewell [[The End Tour]].<ref>{{cite web
column34: title=Rival Sons To Support Black Sabbath On 'The End' World Tour

column4: title=Rival Sons: Great Western Valkyrie - Music Review

column2: Classic Rock]]'' critically lauded the album, giving high praise to the band's pension for \"hardcore rock music with clever lyrics, brilliant guitar playing and superb vocals.\"<ref name=ClassicRock/> Carl Purvis of No Ripcord commented on the band's musicianship throughout the record, finding bassist Dave Beste's chemistry with drummer Michael Miley \"every bit as conversant as the original pairing\", praising the trademark grooves created by guitarist Scott Holiday's \"endless conveyor belt of pulverizing riffs\" and being impressed by Jay Buchanan's vocal performance for having \"the range of [[Chris Cornell]] and the soul of [[Bill Withers]].\"<ref name=NoRipcord/> [[AllMusic]]'s Thom Jurek also praised the musicians for crafting tracks with various aesthetics that are influenced by their \"worship of late-'60s psych, blues-rock, and hard rock\", concluding that \"''Great Western Valkyrie'' continues to revel in retro-rock, but it does so with fine songwriting, arrangements, and -- above all -- taste added to the instrumental firepower. Combined, these strengths make this a full step up from ''[[Head Down (Rival Sons album)

column1: ''Great Western Valkyrie'' charted within the top 40 of several countries, surpassing what ''Head Down'' achieved. The album debuted at numbers 3 and 5 in Finland and Norway respectively, ten and nine spots higher than their previous album.<ref name=AC>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=November 10, 2017}}</ref> It also debuted at numbers 12 and 14 in Switzerland and the UK respectively (whereas their previous record charted at numbers 30 and 31 respectively).<ref name=AC/> However, it fared less better in Austria, the Netherlands and France, entering at numbers 41, 55 and 60 respectively for one week.<ref name=AC/>

column1: All lyrics by Jay Buchanan, except \"Destination on Course\", by Scott Holiday.<ref name=linernotes>{{cite AV media notes
column7: id=MOSH516CD}}</ref> In parentheses are the songs' subtitles which feature on the back cover of the album sleeve.<ref>{{cite web

column1: '''Dissanayake Mudiyanse Ralahamilage Lionel Gamini Dissanayake''' (known as '''Gamini Dissanayake'''; {{lang-si
column3: காமினி திஸாநாயக்க}}; 20 March 1942 – 24 October 1994) was a prominent Sri Lankan politician, a powerful minister of the [[United National Party]], and [[Leader of the Opposition (Sri Lanka)
column4: Leader of the Opposition]]. He was designated as the UNP candidate in the [[1994 Sri Lankan presidential election
column5: 1994 presidential election]], but was then assassinated by the [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]] (LTTE).

column1: He was born in [[Kandy]] as the eldest son of a family of seven children to [[Andrew Dissanayake]] who served as an MP and a deputy minister in the [[Sri Lanka Freedom Party]] government of [[Solomon Bandaranaike
column2: S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike]]. His mother, Welegedara Samaratunga Kumarihamy of Kotmale. Born and bred in Kotmale, his basic values were cultivated in this rural milieu social surrounding and environment. The wealthy Dissanayake family resided in both [[Kandy]] as well as [[Nuwara Eliya]]. Dissanayake had his schooling at the prestigious [[Trinity College (Kandy)
column3: Trinity College]] in Kandy, and received his tertiary education at the [[Sri Lanka Law College]]. Later in life, he completed an MPhil Degree in International Relations at [[Cambridge University]] UK.

column1: <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[File:Gamini Dissanayake statue.jpg
column5:
Gamini Dissanayake statue at
Viharamahadevi Park in Colombo]] -->

column1: Gamini Dissanayake won the 1970 elections and became a member of parliament under UNP candidature and was one of the 18 UNP members in the parliament at a time when his party has faced an humiliating defeat. He comfortably secured his Nuwaraeliya-Maskeliya multielectorate seat in the 1977 elections and was appointed as the minister of Mahaweli Development. Dissanyake spearheaded the [[Mahaweli Development programme
column2: Mahaweli Development Project]]. This was a huge project which was expected to take 30 years to finish. But due to Dissanayake's skills he managed to finish the project within 6 years. The Mahaweli Development Project is the largest development project conducted in Sri Lanka after independence. The whole country was affected by the project which focused on irrigation, hydro power generation, agriculture, town & country development. Further it was criticised by the time as to introduce sinhala population into Tamil's motherland. Majority of the power generated for the local consumption is generated from these hydropower plants while an overwhelming majority of the rice cultivation in Sri Lanka is conducted in these [[Mahaweli]] areas.

column1: He was the chairperson of the Sri Lanka Cricket Board in the early 1980s and helped his country to gain the Test Status in cricket. He played a pivotal role in signing the Indoo-Lanka Peace Accord in 1987. In 1989 he was re elected as a MP from Nuwaraeliya District securing the highest percentage of preferential votes obtained by any UNP MP. He was the Minister of Estate Development during Premadasa regime. He was not awarded a portfolio in 1990 cabinet reshuffle and remained as a back-seat MP in the parliament. Dissanayake was accused of abduction of Prof. Ralph Bultjens. Prof Rohan Goonarathne in an interview with Hasitha Kuruppu told that Dissanayake did that as Bultjens in his lectures accused Dissanayake for swindling of money.<ref>GunaratnaRohan. Interview with Hasitha Kuruppu. Ceylontoday. November 2013</ref> Later he was acquitted from the courts.

He played a major role in the aborted impeachment motion against President Premadasa and as a result was expelled from UNP in 1992. In the same year Dissanayaka joined Lalith Athulathmudali to form United National Democratic Front (DUNF) which was a rising political force of that era. Dissanayaka contested to Kandy District at 1993 provincial council elections and became a member of the Central Provincial Council. After the assassination of Athulathmudali, Dissanayake became the leader of DUNF. Later he rejoined UNP and was appointed to the parliament as a national list MP and was offered a vital portfolio in the Wijethunga Government. In 1994 PA came to power defeating UNP when Dissanayaka was re elected as a member of parliament from Kandy District. In a contest held among UNP MPs to choose the opposition leader Dissanayaka recorded a comfortable victory over Ranil Wickramasinghe.

column2: D.B. Wijetunga]] indicated he would not run in the [[1994 Sri Lankan presidential election
column3: 1994 presidential election]], Dissanayake was selected as the UNP candidate at the same time he was the Leader of the Opposition in parliament.  This was cut short when he was assassinated by a [[female suicide bomber]] of the [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]] (LTTE) while he was addressing an election meeting at Thotalanga.<ref>[http://www.janes.com/security/international_security/news/sentinel/sent000904_6_n.shtml Jane's Sentinel examines the success of the LTTE in resisting the Sri Lankan forces]</ref> Government of India deputed Salim Ali IPS of CBI and [[Tirath Das Dogra
column4: Professor T D Dogra]] of All India Institute of Medical Sciences to assist the investigations of Gamini Dissanayake's assassination.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=WIDOW WANTS INDIAN EXPERTS TO INVESTIGATE ASSASSINATION
column12: accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref> His wife Srima Dissanayake ran in his stead, but was defeated by [[People's Alliance (Sri Lanka)
column13: People's Alliance]] candidate and Prime Minister [[Chandrika Kumaratunga]].

column1: He has two sons, who are active in politics, Navin and Mayantha. His eldest son [[Navin Dissanayake
column2: Navin]] was the Cabinet Minister of State Management Reforms in President [[Mahinda Rajapakse]]'s Government and Member of Parliament for [[Nuwara Eliya District]]; he was non-cabinet Minister of Investment Promotion too.  [[Mayantha Dissanayake
column3: Mayantha]] contested for the [[2010 Sri Lankan parliamentary election
column4: 2010 General Election]] for [[Kandy District]] as a UNP candidate.
